channel.title: Nature on Sheena Cook
channel.description: Recent content in Nature on Sheena Cook

item.title: Derbyshire Details
item.description: A steadiness as that river flows Tree colours natural heraldry Swimming swagger of trout River festival of ducks, geese, gulls The sky a blue canvas Clouds roil in a temporary grey Cattle graze a placid Autumn And we walk through it Feeling gratitude for the grandeur

item.title: Winter Blackbirds
item.description: Even on the dampest day Blackbirds cheerily play Tail fans and chatter Gather for a natter Filling bare trees Flutter and tease Blackbirds style It makes us smile

item.title: Docwra’s Manor
item.description: Following the paths meander Carpets of snowdrops nod To their fellow hellebores Shy crocuses, cheery aconites Euphorbias delighted backdrop Proud orchard trees impress A solitary medlar on a branch Sinous trees reach out Mulberry wisely signifies nature Invokes our faith in nature too Mediterranean courtyard on a February day Grateful to be the sole visitors Time for reflection and introspection Looking at the details everywhere Honesty amongst the pots, the beds and barns Greenhouse a haven of warmth Inhale the comforting scents Succulents the hidden hermits As geraniums slumber in terracotta Propagation and hibernation's lair The gardens gently nurtured Self seeding encouraged; an informality Blooms the bountiful gifts That walls last to embrace And protect so much beauty within The Ravens who created here Were insightful and reflective Along with their loyal gardeners There is honour in what is shared Attuned to horticultural heraldry

item.title: Snowdrops
item.description: Apricity - feeling the sun’s warmth in winter. I loved this word and it falls alongside this poem Confident huddles Frosted foreground In the lee of hedges Purity nodding Come Spring! Come Spring!

item.title: January Morning
item.description: Sun and frost cast Mist rises on a scene Hedges screen Fields of winter barley My misguided longing For the simplicity of Working the land I run with history That of natural beauty.

item.title: Fine Fellows
item.description: Ground frost Makes digging slow Robin watches as I go Beady eyes Bare branch vantage Uncovered habitat advantage Flutters to earth Feeds in the wake Of spades thunk and quake Bold observer Jauntily tilted head Gratefully well fed Gardener's friends In winter’s fading light Robins brings us bright

item.title: Autumn at Pulloxhill
item.description: Pumpkin transformed to a mushy blob, On completion of it’s fearsome job. Cosmos sentinel below a tree. White flowers natural purity. Silent kite floats suspended high. In the grey stillness of the sky. Raking, spreading compost around. Robin brazen on the ground. Then school noises rise, Lunchtime’s whoops and cries. Watch more leaves flutter down. Only warrant a momentary frown. Empty mugs perched on the wall. Gratefully we’d emptied them all.

item.title: Raking Leaves
item.description: Trees slumber. Leaves dress the drive. Damp and dank, Tannins leach brown. Stretch and rake, Rake and gather. Piles grow. Slow……slow…… The next season, Settling in your heart. Satisfaction in effort, That rooks applaud.

item.title: Bees
item.description: If it was nae for the bees Where would we be? Bloody hungry! And there’d be nae honey

item.title: Bramble Patch
item.description: Avoided, unsightly Fearsome thorns that tear. Stop and consider. Listen to birdsong Heralding security within. An insectivorous city Retreat for modest mammals. Gallery of the spider’s webs, Enhanced by crystal dew. Pastel papery flowers. Nectar gatherers buzz, or flutter on elegant wings. A thriving natural community. Self sufficient relinquisher of black pearled berries. We will gratefully share. Appreciate that blackberry thicket For just being there.

item.title: Puffin
item.description: Puffin, puffin You look aloof Until you toddle off a cliff Giving off a fishy whiff. Puffin, puffin Do you have a chuffin? I will nae lie You cannae fly Puffin, puffin You are akin to A short stumpy penguin Kinda cute in a dinner suit

item.title: Owl on a Post
item.description: Bright dawn A silent sentinel On a gate post Staring perfection Bringer of truth Open my eyes To nature’s calm You rise transient Fly shafts of light And gone. Two years on Spiritual stare I question why Maybe always there At peace, serene Wildly wise.

item.title: Woodland and Forest
item.description: And in a forest I shall find The wild in me And that nature is my soul

item.title: Down the Wye
item.description: A canoe on a river We’re the ballast Easy motion Paddles slice water Pewter translucence Rocks soft yellow green Weeds tendril stream We proceed with rhythm:by Swans indifferently serene Kingfisher’s electric flash Reflective purling stretches Momentarily hastens progress Towards Symonds Yat And with regret we leave A river's, sinous steady grace.

item.title: The Best Bakewell Basics
item.description: Sherry and nuts Tartan blanket Show ring dash Ducks on the river Make a splash Sunny days Chatting on the grass Derbyshire strolls Nothing flash Bakewell basic best We deserve the rest

item.title: Winter Walk
item.description: Dark hedgerows where scarlet berries hang Robins who stop to meet your eye Flocks of birds soaring high Pushing the clouds to reveal blue sky And as you walk many a mile Remember there’s been much that made you smile Two dogs hurtle by Proven loyalty makes you sigh A realisation in this open space Family and friends are yours to embrace
